awd_titl_txt: Theory-Driven Experimental Studies of Planar Photocathodes
awd_abstract_narration:
The generation of well-collimated (i.e., bright) pulsed electron beams is a key component in many of todays (and proposed future) cutting edge research instruments aimed at improving our understanding of materials, nanoscale systems, and molecular dynamics on fast timescales and with high spatial resolution.  This research project will build on and verify our recently developed theoretical formalism describing how the characteristics of these electron pulses are fundamentally dependent upon the electronic properties of the electron-emitting (photocathode) material, with the goal of significantly increasing their brightness.  The consequent expected enhancement in the performance of the related research instrumentation (such as the Linac Coherent Light Source and electron microscopes incorporating fast time resolution) should result in tangible scientific advances, particularly in the strategically important fields of sustainable energy research, molecular biochemistry, and materials engineering.  In addition to educating the next generation of leaders in accelerator science, condensed matter physics, and photonics, this project will also expose STEM undergraduate students to highly interdisciplinary modern research work.  

The goal of this three-year research project is to improve substantially the beam quality of laser-driven electron sources using a band structure based photoemission theory to identify robust planar photocathode materials that generate electron beams with ultra-low divergence.  Prior combined experimental and theoretical work has provided the framework for a deeper understanding of the physics of planar photocathodes that will now allow for a predictive approach to photocathode selection.  After experimental verification of the density functional theory (DFT) approach to the simulation of photoemission using single-crystal metals, further studies will be conducted on photocathode materials selected for their substantially reduced electron beam divergence associated with expected low values of the rms transverse momentum, pT, of the emitted electrons.  Assessment of the theoretical predictions will employ the solenoid scan technique to measure pT of electron beams generated using a laser-driven DC electron gun.  All experiments will be performed using a custom-built, 230-300nm tunable ultraviolet laser radiation source to allow in situ verification of the work function and the predicted spectral dependence of quantitative photocathode properties, including quantum emission efficiency.  This will also require an extension to the DFT-based photoemission theory to include finite temperature effects and matrix elements describing the photoexcitation in the photocathode material.  In addition, an investigation into the important effect of surface roughness on the emission properties of planar metal and semiconductor photocathodes with and without direct one-step photoexcited bulk state emission will be initiated.

por.por_cntn:
The research work performed under this NSF award is directed towards improving the electron emission properties of solid-state photocathodes by comparing experimental data to Ab initio based theoretical simulations to advance our understanding of photoemission from these important electron sources.  Of particular interest is to facilitate a reduction in the intrinsic emittance (i.e. divergence) of the electron beam generated from laser-driven solid-state photocathodes.  Even a modest factor of 2-3 reduction in electron beam divergence will allow for a significant improvement in the performance of x-ray free-electron lasers (X-FELs), ultrafast electron diffraction systems, and potential future single-shot imaging electron microscopes with high (sub-nm.ps) space-time resolution; that is, the US scientific infrastructure (in universities and national laboratories) that is at the forefront of research aimed at improving our understanding of atomic-scale dynamics (and hence functionality) of molecules (proteins, drugs, etc.), semiconductors, and many other current and future technological materials. 

 

The primary scientific outcome of the research work has been, to our knowledge, the first successful benchmarking of the measured spectral electron emission properties of oriented single-crystal metal photocathodes (e.g. Rh(110) and Mo(100)) to theoretical evaluations that employ the energy-momentum characteristics of the bulk-band states from which the electrons are emitted.  The developed theoretical photoemission simulation also includes the physics of the vacuum states receiving the photo-electrons – a hitherto omitted consideration.  As a result, this work has provided a roadmap for the more rapid development (or discovery) of new solid-state photocathode materials exhibiting (ultra)low intrinsic emittance and high quantum emission efficiency at room temperature selected using screening tools in Ab initio band structure evaluation techniques.  The first step in this direction has also been taken; the selection of a Hf(0001) photocathode which exhibited half the emittance of conventional metal photocathodes, but proved to be insufficiently robust for use in pulsed ultra-violet laser-driven electron guns. 

 

An important secondary outcome of the research work is the discovery, in collaboration with researchers at the Illinois Institute of Technology and Michigan State University, of a solid-state photocathode that behaves in a distinctly unconventional manner; namely, possesses an intrinsic emittance that decreases (rather than increases) with the incident ultraviolet photon energy.  Although the physical reason for this unusual behavior is not yet understood, this Nitrogen-doped ultra-nanocrystalline diamond may represent a new class of robust solid-state photocathodes that exhibit low intrinsic emittance with high emission efficiency due to quantum confinement effects. 


Last Modified: 10/30/2019
Modified by: W. Andreas Schroeder
